editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

‚ùß A Proclamation concerning New Buildings, in and about the Citie of London, and again≈øt the diuiding of hou≈øes into ≈øeuerall dwellings, and receiuing and harbouring of Inmates.
div.p: WHereas in the fir≈øt yeere of Our Reigne, a≈ø≈øoone as the more important affaires of Our State would giue Vs leaue, taking into Our Princely con≈øideration the ≈øtate of Our Citie of London, being Our Royall Chamber, and the Imperiall ≈øeate of Our Kingdomes, renowned ouer all the parts of Chri≈øtendome, both in re≈øpect of the v≈øuall re≈øidence of Our Royall Per≈øon and Court neere vnto it, the confluence of Forreigne Amba≈ø≈øadours and Strangers thither, the ordinary place for Our Courts of Iu≈øtice, and re≈øort of our Nobilitie and Gentry there for the≈øe occa≈øions;

And fore≈øeeing that the honour, gouernment, health and ≈øafety of this Citie, was of great con≈øequence vnto Vs, and that Our Royall Progenitors in former times (e≈øpecially Our mo≈øt Royall Father of ble≈ø≈øed memory, King IAMES, & the mo≈øt Excellent Prince≈ø≈øe Queene ELIZABETH, in their times) by their Royall Proclamations had carefully prouided for the ≈øame, Wee, according to tho≈øe worthy examples, by Our Royall Proclamation did ≈øtraitly prouide again≈øt the erecting of Hou≈øes & Buildings vpon new Foundations, & the entertaining of Inmates, in and about this Citie, which would multiple the Inhabitants to ≈øuch an exce≈ø≈øiue number, that they could neither be gouerned nor fedd; And did al≈øo thereby giue Rules for the Repairing and new Building of ancient hou≈øes decayed, in ≈øuch a comely manner, with Bricke or Stone, as might bee for the honour and ≈øafety of the Citie; And for the putting of this Our Commandement into due execution, Wee did make, and ≈øeuerall times renew Our Commi≈ø≈øion directed to the Lord Maior of Our ≈øaid Citie, and diuers other per≈øons of honour and worth, grounding the ≈øame vpon rules of Law and Iu≈øtice, as again≈øt publique and common Nu≈øances, a≈øwell as vpon rea≈øon of State and Gouernement, all tending to
the publique good of Our people: But that taking not ≈øo full effect hitherto as Wee expected, Wee have now againe re≈øolued to renew that Our Commi≈ø≈øion to diuers Honourable per≈øons, and others of worth and vnder≈øtanding; And therefore Wee doe hereby publi≈øh and declare Our Royall plea≈øure and Command, That Our ≈øayd Commi≈ø≈øioners for that ≈øeruice, ≈øhall foorthwith a≈øwell by taking a view in their owne per≈øons from time to time, as by all other good wayes and meanes, enquire and finde out the offenders and offences done again≈øt the ≈øeuerall Proclamations made heretofore by Our ≈øaid Father, and by Our Selfe, as again≈øt this pre≈øent Proclamation, and the ≈øame being ≈øo found out, to make certificate thereof vnder their hands, or vnder the hands of two, or more of them, to Our Selfe, as again≈øt this pre≈øent Proclamation, and the ≈øame beeing ≈øo found out, to make certificate thereof vnder their hands, or vnder the hands of two, or more them, to Our Coun≈øell Board, or to binde them ouer to an≈øwere their contempts, either before the Lords of Our Priuie Councell, or in Our Court of Starchamber, to the end that ≈øuch proceeding may bee had again≈øt them, as may ≈øtand with Our Honour and with Our Lawes.

And for ≈øtay and preuention of the like offences hereafter, Our expre≈ø≈øe will and plea≈øure is, That where any per≈øon ≈øhall pre≈øume after the publication of this Proclamation, to erect, or ≈øet vp in any kind what≈øoeuer, any Building vpon new Foundation within the limits of three miles, from any of the Gates of the Citie of London or Palace of We≈øtmin≈øter; That the Owners of the Building ≈øo begun, and all the workemen therein imployed, ≈øhall forthwith by force and vertue of Our Royall commandement (without expecting any other or further Warrant) be attached, & brought before ≈øome of Our ≈øayd Comm≈ø≈øioners and Iu≈øtices of Peace, whom Wee al≈øo hereby require and command, to commit them to Pri≈øon, vntill they ≈øhall find ≈øufficient ≈øureties for ≈øtay of their ≈øayd Building, as al≈øo for their appearance before the Lords of Our Priuie Councell, or in Our high Court of Starchamber, to an≈øwere ≈øuch their contempts, and to vndergoe ≈øuch Sentence, as by that Court ≈øhall bee giuen again≈øt them.

And for ≈øuch as ≈øhall hereafter Reedifie or build vpon did Foundations in any other ≈øort then is pre≈øcribed in Our former Proclamations, and by the In≈øructions herein expre≈ø≈øed; That a≈øwell all ≈øuch Builders, as the workemen therein imployed, ≈øhall bee attached likewi≈øe and proceeded withall as afore≈øaid.

And whereas by Our former Proclamation wee charged and commanded the Aldermen of the Citie of London, and their Deputies, in their ≈øeuerall Wards and Precincts, as likewi≈øe the Iu≈øtices of Peace, High and Petie Con≈øtables, and all other inferiour Officers within their ≈øeuerall limits & Iuri≈ødictions, happening within the ≈øeuerall Counties of Middle≈øex, E≈ø≈øex, Kent, and Surrey, That they and euery of them in their ≈øeuerall places and Offices re≈øpectiuely, ≈øhould diligently and duely attend to giue their vttermo≈øt ayde, helpe, and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance according to their dueties, for the due ob≈øeruance to ≈øee this Our Royall plea≈øure (≈øo much concerning the publique good) to bee duely executed and performed; And where they or any of them ≈øhould finde any offence to bee committed again≈øt any Branch or Article of the ≈øayd Proclamation, to make ≈øtay thereof, and certifie the Commi≈ø≈øioners or the Lords of Our Priuie Councell of the ≈øaid offences and offenders, it being now manife≈øt, that many of the ≈øayd offences haue beene committed and done by the negligence or conniuencie of ≈øome of the Aldermens Deputies within the Citie of London, & other inferiour Officers in the
Counties adiacent, in not attending Our Commandement by timely ≈øtaying the proceeding of ≈øuch new buildings.

Wee therefore doe hereby declare Our will and plea≈øure to be, That where any Building ≈øhall bee begun contrary to this Our Proclamation, Wee will take a ≈øtrict account thereof, a≈øwell from the ≈øaid Aldermen, as the Iu≈øtices of Peace afore≈øayd, happening within their ≈øeuerall limits and Iuri≈ødictions.

And further Our will and plea≈øure is, That a≈øwell the Aldermens Deputies in their ≈øeuerall Precincts, as the High and Petie Con≈øtables, and Headboroughs, and other inferiour Officers in their ≈øeuerall Pari≈øhes, and dwelling in or neere to the place where any ≈øuch new Building ≈øhall happen to bee begun, contrary to the Tenour of this Our Proclamation; And they or ≈øome of them not attaching the per≈øon or per≈øons ≈øo offending, and not bringing them before ≈øome of Our Commi≈ø≈øioners as afore≈øayd, That euery ≈øuch Aldermans Deputie, high Con≈øtable, petie Con≈øtable and Headborough, or other inferiour Officers, ≈øhall be not onely remooued from their ≈øeuerall Places and Offices, but bee committed to the common Gaole of the Citie of London, and Counties of Middle≈øex, E≈ø≈øex, Kent, and Surry, re≈øpectiuely where ≈øuch offence or offences ≈øhall be committed; and euery of them to bee bound with good ≈øureties for his and their good behauiour for one whole yeere then after, to the end that by ≈øuch their puni≈øhment, others may learne the better to performe their duties in this Our Seruice.

And to the end that ≈øuch as doe conforme in their building to the order and forme pre≈øcribed by Vs, may receiue due encouragement by hauing their Materials at rea≈øonable Rates and Prices, which Wee are informed is much inhanced and rai≈øed from the Prices formerly ≈øet by Our Commi≈ø≈øioners: It is therefore Our will and plea≈øure, That Our Commi≈ø≈øioners for Buildings doe call before them all and euery the Brickmakers, and Lime-burners within three miles di≈øtant of London, as al≈øo ≈øuch as doe bring any of the ≈øaid Materials by land or water to the Citie of London, or the places neere adioyning, and doe take order from time to time a≈øwell for the reducing of the Prices thereof to former, v≈øuall and rea≈øonable Rates, or otherwi≈øe according to their good di≈øcretions to bee by them ≈øet, as al≈øo for the pre≈øent and ≈øpeedy ≈øuppre≈ø≈øing of all and euery the Nu≈øances by them dayly committed in their ≈øeuerall profe≈ø≈øions of Brick making and Lime-burning ≈øo neere the Citie of London, and the parts and places adioyning thereunto, and for the ≈øelling of tho≈øe Materials at and for rea≈øonable Rates and Prices, according to the Articles hereafter following.

FIr≈øt, Wee doe ≈øtrictly charge and command, That no dwelling Hou≈øes, Stables, Shops, Stalles, or any other Building what≈øoeuer, bee from hencefoorth erected, or attempted to bee erected within the Citie of London, or the Suburbs thereof, or within the di≈øtance of three miles to bee taken from any Gate of the ≈øayd Citie, or from Our Palace at We≈øtmin≈øter, except it bee vpon the Foundation of a former dwelling hou≈øe, or ≈øuch like Building; And if any ≈øuch Building contrary to this Prohibition ≈øhall hereafter happen to be begunne, that the ≈øame bee foorthwith ≈øtayed from further proceeding, by the Alderman of the Ward, or by two of the next Iu≈øtices of Peace, and a≈øwell ≈øuch Builder, as the Workemen employed therein, committed to Pri≈øon, vntill they ≈øhall enter into ≈øufficient Bond, either to demoli≈øh, & pull downe that which is built, or to an≈øwere their contempt in our high Court of Starchamber, or before the Lords of the Priuy Councell at the Councell Board, And the Con≈øtable of the Pari≈øh or Place, ≈øhall from time to time in the fir≈øt beginning of any
≈øuch Worke or building, giue notice to the Alderman of the Warde, or two next Iu≈øtices of Peace, of any ≈øuch offence, and of the offenders therein, that this Proclamation may bee ≈øpeedily and fre≈øhly put in execution, All Hou≈øes, Sheddes, Shoppes, and other Buildings, which haue beene builded or ≈øet vp within the limits afore≈øaid, at any time ≈øithence the thirteenth yeere of the Reigne of Our ≈øaid late Father King IAMES of ble≈ø≈øed memory, contrary to any Proclamation publi≈øhed in His time, ≈øhall bee foorthwith pulled downe, as is before directed touching other Buildings to be ≈øtayed or pulled downe, and no Cellars erected within the time la≈øt mentioned, to bee v≈øed for Lodgings or Victualling Hou≈øes, but the Occupiers thereof to be ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed, and ≈øo to be kept by the Iu≈øtices of Peace.

THat no per≈øon or per≈øons doe Erect, Reedifie, or ≈øet vp any Hou≈øe, or Building in London, or within the di≈øtance of three miles from any the Gates of the ≈øayd Citie of London, or from Our ≈øaid Palace at We≈øtmin≈øter, vnle≈ø≈øe he doe make all the vtter-Walles of the ≈øame of Bricke, or Bricke and Stone; And that all Hou≈øes and Buildings to be erected within the ≈øayd Citie, or in, or adioyning to any open Streete of any Towne or Village out of the ≈øayd Citie, within the limits of three miles afore≈øayd, ≈øhall bee built according to the forme and proportion hereafter in the≈øe pre≈øents expre≈ø≈øed: (viz.) Euery whole Story of and in ≈øuch Hou≈øes and Buildings, and all & euery the Roomes of ≈øuch whole Story, ≈øhall be of the height of tenne foote of A≈ø≈øize at the lea≈øt, and euery halfe Story of and in ≈øuch Hou≈øes and Buildings, ≈øhall bee of the height of ≈øeuen foote and a halfe at the lea≈øt; And that in the forefront, and all outward and diui≈øion Walles betwixt hou≈øe and hou≈øe, and the Iambes, Heads and ≈øoyles of the Windowes ≈øhall bee of Bricke, or of Bricke and Stone, and the Windowes (being of Timber) not to bee put in vntill the Iambes and Heads afore≈øaid bee fini≈øhed, and beare of them≈øelues.

ANd if the ≈øayd buildings doe not exceede two Stories in height, then the Walles thereof ≈øhall be of the thickne≈ø≈øe of one Bricke and halfe a Brickes length according to the a≈ø≈øize of Brickes hereunder mentioned, from the ground vnto the vppermo≈øt part of the ≈øaid Wals; And where the building ≈øhall be of the height of three Stories, the Walles of the fir≈øt Story ≈øhall bee of the thickne≈ø≈øe of two Brickes length, and from thence vnto the vppermo≈øt part of the Wall of the thickne≈ø≈øe of one Bricke and halfe a brickes length, and ≈øo proportionably, if there ≈øhall bee more Stories.

THat, in building of ≈øaid Hou≈øes there ≈øhall bee no Iu≈øties or Iutting, or Cantwindowes, either vpon Timber Ioi≈øtes, or otherwi≈øe, but the walles to goe direct and ≈øtraight vpwards, and at the ≈øetting of, a water table to bee made; Al≈øo the lights of the windowes of euery whole Story to be of more height then breadth, to the end the Roomes may receiue ayre for health, and there may bee ≈øufficient Peeres of Bricke, not le≈ø≈øe then halfe the bredth of the Windowes betweene them for ≈øtrength; And likewi≈øe the Windowes of euery halfe Story to bee made ≈øquare euery way, or neere thereabouts.

THat all Shops and Streete doores be made with Pilla≈øters of Stone or Bricke, to be in breadth fifteene inches at the lea≈øt, and as thicke as the wall of the Story, and the heads of the Shop-windowes cut in wedges, with Arches ouer them to ≈øu≈øtaine the wall aboue; And that none doe rai≈øe their fir≈øt floore to gaine height in their Cellars, ≈øo as they are thereby forced to make ≈øteppes into the ≈øtreete: Prouided alwayes, that for ≈øo much as concerneth the building with Bricke or Stone, ≈øhall not extend to any Buildings vpon London Bridge, which by rea≈øon of the ≈øituation thereof cannot with conueniencie be ≈øo built.

ANd for the better encouragement of Our louing Subiects in their Buildings, according to the direction of this Proclamation: Wee haue thought fit to ≈øet downe the≈øe orders following concerning the true making and rating of the price of Bricke, which is one of the principall Materials requi≈øite for the ≈øaid buildings: (viz.)

THat the earth whereof the Bricke ≈øhall bee made, bee good and fit for that purpo≈øe, The fir≈øt digging thereof to be betweene the Fea≈øts of S. Michael the Archangel, and S. Thomas
the Apo≈øtle, and the ≈øecond digging, ca≈øting, or turning vp of the ≈øayd earth, to be at or before the la≈øt day of February then following; And that no per≈øon what≈øoeuer doe pre≈øume to digge or make any Bricke in any place within one mile of the Gates of the ≈øaid Citie of London, or within one mile of Our Palace of We≈øtmin≈øter.

THat the ≈øayd earth bee ≈øufficiently and well wrought and tempered before it bee moulded, and the Brickmakers cau≈øe no earth to bee moulded for Bricke, but onely betweene the Fea≈øt of the Annunciation of the ble≈ø≈øed Virgin Mary, and the la≈øt day of Augu≈øt yeerely, and at no other time or ≈øea≈øon of the yeere.

THat in the moulding of the ≈øayd Bricke, the Moulds bee throughly and well filled, and not ≈øet in the Moulds in the laying downe; And that they be ≈øufficiently and well dryed before they be put into the Kilne, and then carefully and throughly wel burned, ≈øo as for the a≈ø≈øize euery Bricke being burned containe in length nine inches, in bredth foure inches one quarter and halfe a quarter of an inch, and in thickne≈ø≈øe two inches and one quarter of an inch.

THat the price of Brickes (being thus wrought and made in goodne≈ø≈øe, ≈øize, and manner as afore≈øayd) ≈øhall not exceede the rate of eight ≈øhillings the thou≈øand at the Kilne; And if any exce≈ø≈øiue rate be demaunded for the carriage of the ≈øayd Brickes from the Kilne to the place where they ≈øhall bee to bee v≈øed, the Commi≈ø≈øioners for buildings to moderate the ≈øame, according to equity in their good di≈øcretions; And that no per≈øon or per≈øons ≈øhall make, or cau≈øe to bee made, within fiue miles of any of the Gates of the Citie of London, nor bring by water or land, or vtter, ≈øell, or put to ≈øale within the ≈øaid Citie, or any place or places within fiue miles thereof, as afore≈øaid, any Brickes made or wrought contrary to the directions afore≈øayd, nor ≈øell the ≈øame at any higher rate then is before mentioned.

THat no per≈øon or per≈øons within the ≈øayd Citie of London, or within three miles from any the Gates thereof, or from Our Palace of We≈øtmin≈øter, ≈øhall in defrauding the intent of this Proclamation, ≈øupport or ≈øtrengthen any Buildings ≈øo ruinous and old, as are vnfit to bee continued, by digging of Cellars, and bringing vp new bricke walles, by erecting new Chimneys and Staire-ca≈øes, by placing of pieces of Timber, by ≈øetting on new Roofes or Rafters, and thru≈øting out of Dormers, knitting and fa≈øtning together the ≈øayd new additions vnto the old Timber, by Barres and Crampes of Iron, or other like deuices, vnle≈ø≈øe hee or they ≈øhall bee thereunto licenced and allowed by Our Commi≈ø≈øioners for Buildings.

THat no per≈øon or per≈øons within the limits la≈øt afore≈øayd, do at any time or times hereafter pre≈øume or attempt, to erect, couer, ouerlay, or inclo≈øe any Houels, or others Sheds of Timber, with Reedes, Faggots, Hay, Straw, Boards, or other Materials, or doe ray≈øe vp any Wall, Pale, or banke of earth, to which Sheds may bee added, or doe repaire or new make into the Streets, any manner of bulkes, ≈øtalles, windowes, doores, or other offen≈øiue i≈ø≈øues, or doe alter or change the v≈øe of any dwelling hou≈øe, or other building, to any more noy≈øome or offen≈øiue v≈øe, end, or purpo≈øe then the ≈øame was imployed before the time of the demoli≈øhing or altering the ≈øame, without the ≈øpeciall licence and allowance of the ≈øayd Commi≈ø≈øioners for buildings. And for that the diuiding of hou≈øes into ≈øeuerall tenements and habitations, and the letting part of hou≈øes and chambers to Inmates and vnder≈øitters, is no le≈ø≈øe inconuenient then exce≈ø≈øiue buildings, a≈øwell in regard of ≈øurcharge of people, e≈øpecially of the wor≈øt ≈øort, and for breeding and ≈øpreading of infection, as otherwi≈øe, Wee doe al≈øo command the≈øe Articles following to bee duely ob≈øerued.

THat no per≈øon or per≈øons within the Citie of London, or three miles from any the Gates thereof, doe diuide any dwelling hou≈øe by Lea≈øe, ≈øufferance, or otherwi≈øe, into, or for any more tenements or dwellings then are at this pre≈øent, or haue beene heretofore v≈øed within the ≈øame by the ≈øpace of thirty yeeres la≈øt pa≈øt.
THat no per≈øon doe hereafter receiue into any hou≈øe, any Inmates or vnder≈øitters, or any more Families then one.

That no per≈øon or per≈øons who ≈øhall erect a new hou≈øe vpon, or within the precincts of an old foundation, ≈øhall diuide the ≈øame into more Tenements, or ≈øeuerall dwellings then were v≈øed in the ≈øaid former hou≈øes.
